timeline.bodyText:
Ah crumbs. I think this is why I had left this part of the method as blocking. If the subscription call returns before getting acknowledgement, we have this new issue - how to do we convey the acknowledgement to the user? It used to be synonymous with getting a subscription ID back.
The user would also need to sleep for a random amount of time, like this test does.
If that part is now async, we can provide the information with a callback. Like:
/**
 * Subscribe to mutations that occur for a given model class.
 * @param clazz Type of model being subscribed
 * @param subscriptionType type of events to subscribe to
 * @param onSubscriptionStarted Called when a subscription begins; a subscription ID is passed
 * @param onNextItem Called when a new subscription item is available
 * @param onSubscriptionFailed Called when the subscription terminates due to a failure
 * @param onSubscriptionCompleted Called when a subscription terminates gracefully
 */
<T extends Model> void subscribe(
    Class<T> clazz,
    SubscriptionType subscriptionType,
    Consumer<String> onSubscriptionStarted,
    Consumer<T> onNextItem,
    Consumer<ApiException> onSubscriptionFailed,
    Action onSubscriptionCompleted
);

Am (irrelevant) note on mechanics, here -- you can use the Sleep#milliseconds(long) test utility to clean things up a bit and get rid of this exception block.
